Fig. 1 Raman spectra of the catalysts 1–4. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the catalysts 1–4. Fig. 3 FT-IR spectra of the catalysts 1–4. Fig. 4 UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the catalysts 1–4. Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts 1–4 fresh and stored for half year. Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of the catalyst 1–4. Scheme 1 Reaction schematic diagram of the O–Mo–propanediol complex and Si–OH of hydrolyzed TEOS. Table 1 Liquid phase epoxidation of propylene over MoO3/SiO2 catalyst. Catalyst X CHP (%) S PO (%) Y PO (%) 1 84 75.1 63.1 2 77 83.5 64.3 3 >99 76.5 75.8 4 >99 85.3 84.5 MoO3 16 3.8 0.6 Effects of preparation procedure in sol–gel method on performance of MoO3/SiO2 catalyst for liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide Yongxia Miao Guanzhong Lu ⁎ Xiaohui Liu Yanglong Guo Yanqin Wang Yun Guo Key Laboratory for Advanced Materials, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 21 64252923; fax: +86 21 64253703. Graphical abstract The MoO3/SiO2 catalyst was synthesized for the epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide. The base-catalyzed sol–gel method is very effective to prepare the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst, but the preparation procedure affects the physicochemical and catalytic properties of the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst significantly. The presence of small size of β-MoO3 and monomeric molybdenum species on SiO2 are in favor of increasing its catalytic performance. The 15% MoO3/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized by a modified base-catalyzed sol–gel method and characterized by Raman, XRD, FT-IR, UV–vis, NH3-TPD and ICP. The catalytic performance of MoO3/SiO2 for the liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) and the effects of preparation procedure on its physicochemical and catalytic properties were studied. The results show that, in the processes of preparing catalyst, the solvent of ammonium heptamolybdate and the sequence of feeding would affect the existing states of molybdenum species on silica support significantly. When 1,2-propanediol was used as the solvent and an appropriate sequence of feeding was adopted, the β-MoO3 species and monomeric molybdenum species can form on silica to make for the promotion of MoO3/SiO2 catalyst. Without any depressor in the reaction system, at 80°C and 2.2MPa for 4h, the conversion of CHP is above 99% and the selectivity to PO reaches 85.3%. Keywords Epoxidation of propylene Cumene hydroperoxide MoO3/SiO2 catalyst Catalyst preparation 1 Introduction Molybdenum-containing complexes, especially the oxomolybdenum species, have been widely investigated, because of their high activities for the selective oxidation [1–4]. One example is the soluble molybdenum naphthenate catalyst patented for the epoxidation of propylene with tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) in a homogeneous phase (Halcon process) [5]. Because of the well-known disadvantages of homogeneous catalysis, in recent years the considerable efforts have been paid to the heterogenization of molybdenum species on different supports, such as polymer [6–9] or silica [10–13], by covalently grafting homogeneous molybdenum catalysts. However, polymer supports suffer the swelling or dissolving in the organic solvents, and silica supports (such as mesoporous silica MCM-41) need various mono- or bidentate ligands to functionalize its surface so that the covalent bonds can be formed between the catalytic active compounds and the support. In the processes of preparing catalyst mentioned above, the molybdenum complexes must be used as molybdenum precursor. However, the synthesis of these complexes is difficult and uneconomical so that it is impossible to be used commercially. Silica-supported molybdenum oxide (MoO3/SiO2) prepared by an impregnation method or sol–gel method has been used as a catalyst in a variety of reactions, such as the olefin metathesis [14], selective oxidation [15], oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes [16] and photocatalytic oxidation of CO [17]. It has also been used extensively to catalyze the selective oxidation of methane to methanol [18–20]. However, few papers reported that MoO3/SiO2 was used as a catalyst in the liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide (CHP), which is an important industrial process commercialized in March 2003 by Sumitomo using titanium-based catalyst [21]. The MoO3/SiO2 catalyst has been developed to catalyze the liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with CHP in our laboratory, which was synthesized by the acid-catalyzed sol–gel method [22]. The reaction temperature must be kept above 100°C to obtain reasonable conversion and the basic depressor was needed in the reaction system in order to increase the selectivity to propylene oxide (PO). However, the high reaction temperature accelerates easily the decomposition of CHP, resulting in a decrease in the selectivity of PO. In this paper, a modified base-catalyzed sol–gel method was used to prepare the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst for the liquid phase epoxidation of propylene by CHP without any depressor or additives, in which ammonium heptamolybdate and tetraethylorthosilicate were used as a molybdenum and silica source, respectively. In the sol–gel method, the structure of the synthesis gel would be affected significantly by the preparation procedure, resulting in the change in physicochemical and catalytic properties of synthesized catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS), ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O), ethanol (EtOH) from commercial sources were used without any pre-treatment. De-ionized water was adjusted by ammonia to pH 9.1 to catalyze the hydrolyzation of TEOS. All the catalysts were prepared by a sol–gel method and their composition are 15wt% MoO3 on SiO2. Method 1: 20ml TEOS was dissolved in 20ml ethanol, followed by adding 40ml water with pH 9.1. After it was stirred vigorously at 80°C for 30min, 40ml aqueous solution of ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 1.2g) was added dropwise. Then this mixture solution was stirred for 10min and aged at 80°C for 3h, to obtain a homogeneous gel. Method 2: Different from Method 1, 1.2g ammonium heptamolybdate was dissolved in 8.5g 1,2-propanediol but not in water to be added. Other steps are the same as Method 1. Method 3: TEOS (20ml), EtOH (20ml) and 1,2-propanediol solution (8.5g) of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (1.2g) were mixed together, then 80ml water with pH 9.1 was added dropwise under vigorous stirring at 80°C. This mixture was stirred for 10min and then aged at 80°C for 3h. Method 4: Different from Method 3, the feeding sequence was reversed. Firstly, 80ml water with pH 9.1 was charged in the rockered flask, then the mixture of TEOS, EtOH and 1,2-propanediol solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was added dropwise under vigorous stirring at 80°C. Other steps are the same as Method 3. All gels were aged for 7 days at room temperature before drying at 100°C for 24h to remove excess solvent and water, and calcined in air at 550°C for 5h to get four catalysts, which were remarked to the catalysts 1–4. As a reference, unsupported MoO3 was prepared by the calcination of ammonium heptamolybdate at 350°C, and its amount used in the reaction is equal to the loading of MoO3 in the supported MoO3 catalyst. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The XRD measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/max-2550VB/PC diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40kV and 100mA. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 670 FT-IR spectrometer, and the sample to be measured was ground with KBr and pressed into thin wafer. The laser Raman spectra of samples were obtained on a Renishaw Raman spectrometer at ambient condition. The 514nm line of a Spectra Physics Ar+ laser was used for excitation. The UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary 500 spectrophotometer using the diffuse reflectance technique in the range of 200–800nm, and BaSO4 was used as the reference. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 adsorbed on a catalyst (NH3-TPD) was carried out on a conventional flow system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The sample was pre-treated in helium at 550°C for 1h before adsorbing NH3. The NH3-TPD experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 100–600°C in a flow of dry He (30ml/min). The rate of heating was 10°C/min. The temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 100–900°C in a flow of dry 10% H2/N2 (50ml/min). The rate of heating was 10°C/min. The molybdenum content in the catalyst was determined by an inductively coupled argon plasma (ICP, TJA IRIS 1000) after the sample was solved in the solution of HF-HCl. 2.3 Catalytic epoxidation of propylene The epoxidation reaction of propylene was carried out in an autoclave (100ml) placed in a temperature equilibrated oil bath. In a typical experiment, the mixture of 20ml tert-butyl alcohol, 10ml cumene hydroperoxide (48%, industrial grade) and 0.1g catalyst was placed into autoclave, and then 0.5MPa propylene gas was charged at 6°C. After this reaction mixture was heated to 80°C under magnetical stirring, the system pressure increased from ∼0.5MPa at 6°C to 2.2MPa at 80°C and it was kept at 80°C for 4h. After the end of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled immediately in an ice-bath before opening the reactor, and the liquid phase at about 0°C was analyzed. The propylene oxide was analyzed by Clarus 500 Gas Chromatograph (PerkinElmer) equipped with a FID detector and AE.PEG-20M separation column (30m×0.32mm), and toluene was used as an internal standard. The conversion of CHP was determined by an iodometric analysis. The conversion of CHP (X CHP), the selectivity to PO (S PO) for CHP and the yield of PO (Y PO) are calculated as follows: X CHP ( % ) = n CHP i − n CHP t n CHP i × 100 , S PO ( % ) = n PO n CHP i − n CHP t × 100 , Y PO ( % ) = ( S CHP × X CHP ) × 100 wherein n CHP i and n CHP t are the initial and terminal mole numbers of CHP in the reaction mixture, respectively; n PO is the mole number of PO produced. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 ICP analysis The MoO3 contents in the MoO3/SiO2 catalysts were analyzed by the ICP technique. The results show that, the MoO3 contents of the catalysts 1–4 are 11.7%, 14.5%, 12.5% and 12.9%, respectively. It has been proved that most of molybdenum species in the synthesis sol have been supported on the silica support. 3.1.2 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is an effective way to study the metal oxide supported on SiO2. It is well known that, in the Raman spectrum of supported molybdenum oxide the bands at 992, 820 and 666cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching mode of the terminal MoO groups, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the Mo–O–Mo bridges in α-MoO3, respectively; the bands at 851 and 781cm−1 can be assigned to the typical bands of β-MoO3; the broad bands centered at around 950 and 875cm−1 can be assigned to a highly dispersed surface polymolybdate [23]. Huong et al. [24] thought that Raman absorption bands of β-MoO3 is different from α-MoO3, that is, the α-MoO3 exhibits the band at 997cm−1 and β-MoO3 exhibits the symmetric stretch band of Mo–O–Mo at 777cm−1. Fig. 1 shows the Raman spectra of the four MoO3/SiO2 catalysts. The broad bands at ∼870 and 956cm−1 for all the samples may be ascribed to the antisymmetric stretching of Mo–O–Mo and MoO stretching of surface polymolybdenum species, respectively. The bands at ∼995, 819 and 666cm−1 for the catalysts 2–4 may be assigned to the α-MoO3 species. For the catalyst 1, the most intensive peak of α-MoO3 species at 819cm−1 is very small, which indicates there are a small quantity of MoO3 crystallites in the catalyst 1. The bands at ∼845 and 772cm−1 for the catalysts 3 and 4 may be ascribed to the β-MoO3 species. The band at 714cm−1 appears only in the Raman spectrum of the catalyst 4 and may be ascribed to the monomeric molybdenum species, based on the results reported by Verbruggen et al. [25]. In Verbruggen's works, this band has been observed in the Raman spectrum of Mo–K–O/silica with the ratio of K/Mo equaling to the stoichiometric composition of K2MoO4, and was ascribed to the formation of monomeric species. The results above show that, highly dispersed polymolybdate species, α-MoO3 species, β-MoO3 species and monomeric molybdenum species can coexist on the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst, however their contents depend on different solvents and different procedures in the preparation of MoO3/SiO2. In the catalyst 1 synthesized by using de-ionized water as the solvent of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, only a small quantity of crystal α-MoO3 exist except for polymolybdate species. Being different from the catalyst 1, 1,2-propanediol was used as a solvent instead of de-ionized water in the preparation of the catalysts 2–4. There are much more α-MoO3 crystallites in the catalyst 2 than in the catalyst 1. Changing the procedure of feeding, α- and β-MoO3 species can be formed in the catalysts 3 and 4. When the oil phase was dropped into the water phase in the preparation of the catalyst 4, the monomeric molybdenum species can be formed. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the four 15wt% MoO3/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the sol–gel method. Except for the catalyst 2 that has the typical diffraction peaks of crystal MoO3 at 2θ (°)=12.7, 23.3, 25.6, 27.2 and 38.9, other three catalysts display the characteristic diffraction peaks of amorphous silica and no peaks of MoO3, which shows that the molybdenum species are highly dispersed on the support or the MoO3 crystallites are too small to detect by XRD. It has been found from the Raman spectra in Fig. 1 that there are the MoO3 crystallites in the catalysts 3 and 4, however no diffraction peaks of MoO3 can be observed in their XRD patterns, which indicates that the sizes of MoO3 crystallites are below 5nm of the detection limit of XRD. 3.1.4 Infrared and UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopies The FT-IR spectra and the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the four MoO3/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , respectively. In the FT-IR spectra, the intensive absorption bands at around 1090, 800 and 460cm−1 are ascribed to Si–O vibration of SiO2, and the broad band centered at about 960cm−1 with a shoulder at about 920cm−1 for all the samples is the sign of supported molybdenum species. Generally, silicomolybdic acid (SMA) has the equal intensive absorption bands at 956 and 910cm−1, which are assigned to the terminal MoO bond and Mo–O–Si bond in crystal SMA, respectively [24]. The absorption peak at 975cm−1 is assigned to the terminal MoO bond of distorted polymolybdate ions (such as Mo7O24 6− and Mo8O26 4−) [18]. Therefore, the presence of the weaker peak at about ∼920cm−1 proves the existence of a few of SMA on all catalysts, which can form by exposing MoO3/SiO2 sample in air at room temperature. The broad band centered at about 960cm−1 can be attributed to the overlapping of MoO bonds of SMA and polymolybdate ions. The typical bands of crystal MoO3 are not observed, which are located at about 990, 880 and 620cm−1 corresponding to the vibrations of MoO stretching, Mo–O–Mo stretching and Mo–O–Mo bending of MoO3, respectively. All the samples display a similar broad band ending at 440–475nm in the UV–vis spectra shown in Fig. 4. Generally, the bands located in the region of 200–250nm are attributed to the presence of isolated Mo6+ species [26], which shows a good dispersion of Mo species. The signal centered at 290nm is assigned to the electrons transitions caused by Mo–O–Mo bonds in the oligomerized molybdate species [27]. The absorption at over 320nm is attributed to the electrons transitions in the dense phase of MoO3 [28]. The broad band can be considered as the overlapping of the absorption bands at 200–250, 290 and 320nm, and indicates the coexistence of a variety of molybdenum species. 3.1.5 Temperature-programmed reduction The different structures of molybdate species on support would represent different reducibility [29,30]. Therefore, the reduction peaks of MoO3/SiO2 are related to the oxospecies of molybdenum on the surface of support. Fig. 5 shows the TPR profiles of fresh catalysts 1–3 and catalysts 3 and 4 stored for half year. It can be seen that there are two reduction peaks below 900°C for fresh catalysts. The first peak is located at about 550°C and the second is at about 750°C. The low temperature peak is assigned to reduction of octahedral molybdenum oxide and the high temperature peak is assigned to reduction of tetrahedral molybdenum oxide species [31]. That is to say, the octahedral and tetrahedral molybdenum oxide species coexist on the MoO3/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the different methods. Molybdenum oxide can be highly dispersed in mono-layer on SiO2 support until its amount is up to certain value [32], then the mono-species would aggregate into poly-species or crystallite species. The octahedral molybdenum oxide species should include the crystal species of α-MoO3, β-MoO3 and some polymolybdate species; the tetrahedral molybdenum oxide species should include the monomeric and polymolybdate dispersed in mono-layer on silica. For the catalysts 3 and 4 stored for half year, the high temperature peak weakened remarkably, and the low temperature peak slightly enlarged and broadened with a small shoulder peak located in side of high temperature and shifted to the lower temperature, which brings forward two questions: one is that the tetrahedral molybdenum species dispersed in mono-layer may migrate and aggregate to the octahedral molybdenum oxide species, however the low temperature reduction peak only enlarges slightly, which may be due to the limits of reduction degree of molybdenum oxide and the surface area of sample; another is that the change in the tetrahedral molybdenum oxide species with the time may have taken place, which leads to the decline of its reduction property. To solve the questions above, the change in the physicochemical properties of the molybdenum oxide species supported on SiO2 with the time are studying, and the results will be reported specifically. 3.2 Epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide The catalytic performances of the four catalysts were tested for the liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with CHP at 80°C for 4h and the results are listed in Table 1 . The results show that, unsupported MoO3 exhibits very low catalytic activity and selectivity, and there is a great difference in the catalytic activity and selectivity between four supported catalysts. The order of the catalytic activity is the catalyst 3=catalyst 4>catalyst 1>catalyst 2>unsupported MoO3, and for the selectivity to PO, the catalyst 4 is higher than the catalyst 3. As we relate the composition of the surface molybdenum species with their catalytic performances, it can be found that the higher catalytic activity of the catalysts 3 and 4 may be attributed to the small crystal β-MoO3 of below than 5nm, which cannot be detected in the catalysts 1 and 2. The higher selectivity of the catalyst 4 may be ascribed to the monomeric molybdenum species that can only be detected in this catalyst. That is to say, the small crystal β-MoO3 of below 5nm and monomeric molybdenum species are in favor of improving the catalytic performance of the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst. The poor performance of unsupported MoO3 and the catalyst 2 should be attributed to the α-MoO3 phase with bigger crystal size. 3.3 Discussions During the preparation of MoO3/SiO2 catalyst, the complex (a) of O–Mo–propanediol (Scheme 1 ) can form easily in the 1,2-propanediol solution of ammonium heptamolybdate [33], and reacts with Si–OH of hydrolyzed tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) to form the compound (b) (Scheme 1). By the thermal decomposition of the compound (b) during a calcination, the molybdenum-containing species on silica can be redistributed, resulting in the improvement of the performance of catalyst, such as the catalysts 2–4. In the process of preparing catalyst, the sequence of feeding is also very important for a high effective catalyst, such as the catalyst 4 behaving higher activity and selectivity than the catalysts 2 and 3. In the preparation of catalyst 2, TEOS was well pre-hydrolyzed before adding the molybdenum compound, so that more O–Mo–propanediol complexes could not react effectively with Si–OH and would aggregate promoted by water. Due to the low concentration of exposed Si–OH, relatively bigger crystal MoO3 species form easily after being calcined. In the preparation of the catalysts 3 and 4, TEOS and ammonium heptamolybdate are well mixed, and the complex (a) can react easily with Si–OH of hydrolyzed tetraethylorthosilicate to form the compound (b) (Scheme 1). During the calcination, some adjacent Mo ions may migrate and coagulate to form finely divided α- and β-MoO3 crystallites. However, the reverse feeding sequence of water and oil phase would lead to a change in pH value of the sol, and affect the hydrolyzation and agglomeration speeds of TEOS, resulting in a change in the texture of synthesis gel. Unsupported β-MoO3 is a metastable phase, and will change to the thermodynamically stable phase such as α-MoO3 when it is heated at 400°C [34]. Although as-made catalysts were calcined at 550°C, the β-MoO3 species still exist on SiO2 when 1,2-propanediol was used as a solvent instead of de-ionized water in the preparation of synthesis solution. This phenomenon is caused by the existence of O–Mo–propanediol complexes that may cause the rearrangement of Mo–O–Mo, resulting in the formation of octahedral β-MoO3 species with only corner-linked MoO6. The proper acidity of the active sites is necessary for the olefin epoxidation with hydroperoxide [35]. However, the presence of acid sites would also catalyze the open-ring hydrolyzation of PO, resulting in a decrease in the selectivity to PO. In order to determine the acidic property of the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst, NH3-TPD on the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst has been performed and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that the four catalysts have similar lower surface acidity, which indicates the surface acidity of MoO3/SiO2 is not a key factor to decrease the PO selectivity. In fact, only trace of propanediol was detected in the epoxidation of propylene with CHP over MoO3/SiO2, which shows that the open-ring hydrolysis of PO is not the main reason for a decrease in the epoxidation selectivity. The catalytic reaction of PO with CHP over the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst was performed to determine the possible deep reaction of PO in the epoxidation of propylene. The results showed that no acetone or other carbonyl compounds were detected, and the product was only a small amount of propanediol from the hydrolysis of PO. Water came from the feedstock of CHP and the dehydration of 2-phenyl-2-propanol to 2-phenyl-1-propylene, which is the byproduct formed in the epoxidation of propylene with CHP. The decomposition of CHP in the absence of propylene was performed to determine the possibility of decomposition reaction of CHP. The results showed that there were several products from the decomposition of CHP, including phenol, acetone, α-methylstyrene, hypnone, dimethyl benzyl alcohol. These experiments prove that the decomposition of CHP catalyzed by the acidic sites on the catalyst or thermal activation makes the epoxidation selectivity decrease, in the epoxidation of propylene with CHP over MoO3/SiO2. 4 Conclusions MoO3/SiO2 prepared by a modified base-catalyzed sol–gel method, is an effective catalyst for the liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide. Depending on different preparation procedures and different solvents, a variety of molybdenum-containing species can be formed on silica support, including highly dispersed polymolybdate, α-MoO3, β-MoO3, monomeric molybdenum species, and a small amount of SMA that was formed due to exposure to air. The presences of small size (below 5nm) of β-MoO3 and monomeric molybdenum species are in favor of an increase in the catalytic performance of MoO3/SiO2. Using 1,2-propanediol as a solvent instead of de-ionized water and adopting appropriate sequence of feeding, the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst with the β-MoO3 species and monomeric molybdenum species can be prepared and behaves very high catalytic activity. At 80°C and 2.2MPa for 4h, the conversion of CHP and selectivity to PO for CHP over the MoO3/SiO2 catalyst can reach >99% and 85.3%, respectively. Acknowledgments We would like to acknowledge the financial support of the National Basic Research Program of China (2004CB719500) and the Commission of Science and Technology of Shanghai Municipality (06JC14095). coredata.dc:description: The 15% MoO3/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized by a modified base-catalyzed sol–gel method and characterized by Raman, XRD, FT-IR, UV–vis, NH3-TPD and ICP. The catalytic performance of MoO3/SiO2 for the liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) and the effects of preparation procedure on its physicochemical and catalytic properties were studied. The results show that, in the processes of preparing catalyst, the solvent of ammonium heptamolybdate and the sequence of feeding would affect the existing states of molybdenum species on silica support significantly. When 1,2-propanediol was used as the solvent and an appropriate sequence of feeding was adopted, the β-MoO3 species and monomeric molybdenum species can form on silica to make for the promotion of MoO3/SiO2 catalyst. Without any depressor in the reaction system, at 80°C and 2.2MPa for 4h, the conversion of CHP is above 99% and the selectivity to PO reaches 85.3%.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of preparation procedure in sol–gel method on performance of MoO3/SiO2 catalyst for liquid phase epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide
